# Glycoprotein

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

Not to be confused with [peptidoglycan](/wiki/Peptidoglycan "Peptidoglycan"),
[proteoglycan](/wiki/Proteoglycan "Proteoglycan"), or
[glycopeptide](/wiki/Glycopeptide "Glycopeptide").

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ed/Glicoprotein.svg/220px-
Glicoprotein.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Glicoprotein.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Glicoprotein.svg "Enlarge")

N-linked protein glycosylation (N-glycosylation of N-glycans) at Asn residues
(Asn-x-Ser/Thr motifs) in glycoproteins.[1]

**Glycoproteins** are [proteins](/wiki/Protein "Protein") which contain
[oligosaccharide](/wiki/Oligosaccharide "Oligosaccharide") chains
([glycans](/wiki/Glycans "Glycans")) [covalently](/wiki/Covalent_bond
"Covalent bond") attached to [amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") side-
chains. The carbohydrate is attached to the protein in a
[cotranslational](/wiki/Translation_\(genetics\) "Translation \(genetics\)")
or [posttranslational modification](/wiki/Posttranslational_modification
"Posttranslational modification"). This process is known as
[glycosylation](/wiki/Glycosylation "Glycosylation"). [Secreted extracellular
proteins](/wiki/Secretory_protein "Secretory protein") are often glycosylated.

In proteins that have segments extending extracellularly, the extracellular
segments are also often glycosylated. Glycoproteins are also often important
[integral membrane proteins](/wiki/Integral_membrane_proteins "Integral
membrane proteins"), where they play a role in cell–cell interactions. It is
important[_[according to
whom?](/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Words_to_watch#Unsupported_attributions
"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Words to watch")_] to distinguish endoplasmic
reticulum-based glycosylation of the secretory system from reversible
cytosolic-nuclear glycosylation. Glycoproteins of the [cytosol](/wiki/Cytosol
"Cytosol") and nucleus can be modified through the reversible addition of a
single GlcNAc residue that is considered reciprocal to phosphorylation and the
functions of these are likely to be additional regulatory mechanism that
controls phosphorylation-based signalling.[2] In contrast, classical secretory
glycosylation can be structurally essential. For example, inhibition of
asparagine-linked, i.e. N-linked, glycosylation can prevent proper
glycoprotein folding and full inhibition can be toxic to an individual cell.
In contrast, perturbation of glycan processing (enzymatic removal/addition of
carbohydrate residues to the glycan), which occurs in both the [endoplastic
reticulum](/wiki/Endoplasmic_reticulum "Endoplasmic reticulum") and [Golgi
apparatus](/wiki/Golgi_apparatus "Golgi apparatus"), is dispensable for
isolated cells (as evidence by survival with glycosides inhibitors) but can
lead to human disease (congenital disorders of glycosylation) and can be
lethal in animal models. It is therefore likely that the fine processing of
glycans is important for endogenous functionality, such as cell trafficking,
but that this is likely to have been secondary to its role in host-pathogen
interactions. A famous example of this latter effect is the [ABO blood group
system](/wiki/ABO_blood_group_system "ABO blood group system").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

## Types of
glycosylation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Glycoprotein&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Types of glycosylation")]

There are several types of glycosylation, although the first two are the most
common.

  * In [N-glycosylation](/wiki/N-linked_glycosylation "N-linked glycosylation"), sugars are attached to nitrogen, typically on the [amide](/wiki/Amide "Amide") side-chain of [asparagine](/wiki/Asparagine "Asparagine").
  * In [O-glycosylation](/wiki/O-linked_glycosylation "O-linked glycosylation"), sugars are attached to oxygen, typically on [serine](/wiki/Serine "Serine") or [threonine](/wiki/Threonine "Threonine"), but also on [tyrosine](/wiki/Tyrosine "Tyrosine") or non-canonical amino acids such as [hydroxylysine](/wiki/Hydroxylysine "Hydroxylysine") & [hydroxyproline](/wiki/Hydroxyproline "Hydroxyproline").
  * In [P-glycosylation](/w/index.php?title=P-linked_glycosylation&action=edit&redlink=1 "P-linked glycosylation \(page does not exist\)"), sugars are attached to [phosphorus](/wiki/Phosphorous_acid "Phosphorous acid") on a [phosphoserine](/wiki/Phosphoserine "Phosphoserine").
  * In [C-glycosylation](/w/index.php?title=C-linked_glycosylation&action=edit&redlink=1 "C-linked glycosylation \(page does not exist\)"), sugars are attached directly to carbon, such as in the addition of [mannose](/wiki/Mannose "Mannose") to [tryptophan](/wiki/Tryptophan "Tryptophan").
  * In [S-glycosylation](/w/index.php?title=S-linked_glycosylation&action=edit&redlink=1 "S-linked glycosylation \(page does not exist\)"), a beta-[GlcNAc](/wiki/GlcNAc "GlcNAc") is attached to the sulfur atom of a [cysteine](/wiki/Cysteine "Cysteine") residue[3].
  * In [glypiation](/wiki/Glypiation "Glypiation"), a [GPI](/wiki/Glycophosphatidylinositol "Glycophosphatidylinositol") glycolipid is attached to the C-terminus of a polypeptide, serving as a membrane anchor.
  * In [glycation](/wiki/Glycation "Glycation"), also known as non-enzymatic glycosylation, sugars are covalently bonded to a protein or lipid molecule, without the controlling action of an enzyme, but through a [Maillard reaction](/wiki/Maillard_reaction "Maillard reaction").

##
Monosaccharides[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Glycoprotein&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Monosaccharides")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cf/Glykoproteine_Zucker.svg/220px-
Glykoproteine_Zucker.svg.png)](/wiki/File:Glykoproteine_Zucker.svg)

[](/wiki/File:Glykoproteine_Zucker.svg "Enlarge")

Eight sugars commonly found in glycoproteins.

Monosaccharides commonly found in eukaryotic glycoproteins include:[4]:526

The principal sugars found in human glycoproteins[5] Sugar  | Type  | Abbreviation   
---|---|---  
[β-D-Glucose](/wiki/Glucose "Glucose") | [Hexose](/wiki/Hexose "Hexose") | Glc   
[β-D-Galactose](/wiki/Galactose "Galactose") | Hexose  | Gal   
[β-D-Mannose](/wiki/Mannose "Mannose") | Hexose  | Man   
[α-L-Fucose](/wiki/Fucose "Fucose") | [Deoxyhexose](/wiki/Deoxy_sugar "Deoxy sugar") | Fuc   
[N-Acetylgalactosamine](/wiki/N-Acetylgalactosamine "N-Acetylgalactosamine") | [Aminohexose](/wiki/Aminosugar "Aminosugar") | GalNAc   
[N-Acetylglucosamine](/wiki/N-Acetylglucosamine "N-Acetylglucosamine") | Aminohexose  | GlcNAc   
[N-Acetylneuraminic acid](/wiki/N-Acetylneuraminic_acid "N-Acetylneuraminic acid") | [Aminononulosonic acid](/wiki/Neuraminic_acid "Neuraminic acid")  
([Sialic acid](/wiki/Sialic_acid "Sialic acid"))  | NeuNAc   
[Xylose](/wiki/Xylose "Xylose") | [Pentose](/wiki/Pentose "Pentose") | Xyl   
  
The sugar group(s) can assist in [protein folding](/wiki/Protein_folding
"Protein folding"), improve proteins' stability and are involved in cell
signalling.

## Examples[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Glycoprotein&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Examples")]

One example of glycoproteins found in the body is [mucins](/wiki/Mucin
"Mucin"), which are secreted in the mucus of the respiratory and digestive
tracts. The sugars when attached to mucins give them considerable water-
holding capacity and also make them resistant to
[proteolysis](/wiki/Proteolysis "Proteolysis") by digestive enzymes.

Glycoproteins are important for [white blood cell](/wiki/White_blood_cell
"White blood cell") recognition.[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]
Examples of glycoproteins in the [immune system](/wiki/Immune_system "Immune
system") are:

  * molecules such as [antibodies](/wiki/Antibody "Antibody") (immunoglobulins), which interact directly with [antigens](/wiki/Antigen "Antigen").
  * molecules of the _[major histocompatibility complex](/wiki/Major_histocompatibility_complex "Major histocompatibility complex")_ (or MHC), which are expressed on the surface of cells and interact with [T cells](/wiki/T_cell "T cell") as part of the adaptive immune response.
  * sialyl Lewis X antigen on the surface of leukocytes.

H antigen of the ABO blood compatibility antigens. Other examples of
glycoproteins include:

  * gonadotropins (luteinizing hormone a follicle-stimulating hormone)
  * [glycoprotein IIb/IIIa](/wiki/Glycoprotein_IIb/IIIa "Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa"), an integrin found on [platelets](/wiki/Platelet "Platelet") that is required for normal platelet aggregation and adherence to the [endothelium](/wiki/Endothelium "Endothelium").
  * components of the [zona pellucida](/wiki/Zona_pellucida "Zona pellucida"), which surrounds the [oocyte](/wiki/Oocyte "Oocyte"), and is important for [sperm](/wiki/Sperm "Sperm")-egg interaction.
  * structural glycoproteins, which occur in [connective tissue](/wiki/Connective_tissue "Connective tissue"). These help bind together the fibers, cells, and ground substance of [connective tissue](/wiki/Connective_tissue "Connective tissue"). They may also help components of the tissue bind to inorganic substances, such as [calcium](/wiki/Calcium "Calcium") in [bone](/wiki/Bone "Bone").
  * Glycoprotein-41 ([gp41](/wiki/Gp41 "Gp41")) and glycoprotein-120 ([gp120](/wiki/Gp120 "Gp120")) are HIV viral coat proteins.

Soluble glycoproteins often show a high [viscosity](/wiki/Viscosity
"Viscosity"), for example, in [egg white](/wiki/Egg_white "Egg white") and
[blood plasma](/wiki/Blood_plasma "Blood plasma").

  * [Miraculin](/wiki/Miraculin "Miraculin"), is a glycoprotein extracted from _[Synsepalum dulcificum](/wiki/Synsepalum_dulcificum "Synsepalum dulcificum")_ a [berry](/wiki/Berry "Berry") which alters human tongue receptors to recognize sour foods as sweet.[6]

[Variable surface glycoproteins](/wiki/Variable_surface_glycoprotein "Variable
surface glycoprotein") allow the sleeping sickness _Trypanosoma_ parasite to
escape the immune response of the host.

The viral spike of the human immunodeficiency virus is heavily
glycosylated.[7] Approximately half the mass of the spike is glycosylation and
the glycans act to limit antibody recognition as the glycans are assembled by
the host cell and so are largely 'self'. Over time, some patients can evolve
antibodies to recognise the HIV glycans and almost all so-called 'broadly
neutralising antibodies (bnAbs) recognise some glycans. This is possible
mainly because the unusually high density of glycans hinders normal glycan
maturation and they are therefore trapped in the premature, high-mannose,
state.[8][9] This provides a window for immune recognition. In addition, as
these glycans are much less variable than the underlying protein, they have
emerged as promising targets for vaccine design.[10]

## Hormones[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Glycoprotein&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Hormones")]

[Hormones](/wiki/Hormone "Hormone") that are glycoproteins include:

  * [Follicle-stimulating hormone](/wiki/Follicle-stimulating_hormone "Follicle-stimulating hormone")
  * [Luteinizing hormone](/wiki/Luteinizing_hormone "Luteinizing hormone")
  * [Thyroid-stimulating hormone](/wiki/Thyroid-stimulating_hormone "Thyroid-stimulating hormone")
  * [Human chorionic gonadotropin](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin "Human chorionic gonadotropin")
  * [Alpha-fetoprotein](/wiki/Alpha-fetoprotein "Alpha-fetoprotein")
  * [Erythropoietin (EPO)](/wiki/Erythropoietin "Erythropoietin")

## Functions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Glycoprotein&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Functions")]

Some functions served by glycoproteins[4]:524 Function  | Glycoproteins   
---|---  
Structural molecule  | [Collagens](/wiki/Collagen "Collagen")  
Lubricant and protective agent  | [Mucins](/wiki/Mucin "Mucin")  
Transport molecule  | [Transferrin](/wiki/Transferrin "Transferrin"), [ceruloplasmin](/wiki/Ceruloplasmin "Ceruloplasmin")  
Immunologic molecule  | [Immunoglobulins](/wiki/Antibody "Antibody"),[11] [histocompatibility](/wiki/Histocompatibility "Histocompatibility") antigens   
Hormone  | [Human chorionic gonadotropin](/wiki/Human_chorionic_gonadotropin "Human chorionic gonadotropin") (HCG), thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH)   
Enzyme  | Various, e.g., alkaline [phosphatase](/wiki/Phosphatase "Phosphatase"), [patatin](/wiki/Patatin "Patatin")  
Cell attachment-recognition site  | Various proteins involved in cell–cell (e.g., [sperm](/wiki/Sperm "Sperm")–[oocyte](/wiki/Oocyte "Oocyte")), virus–cell, bacterium–cell, and hormone–cell interactions   
[Antifreeze protein](/wiki/Antifreeze_protein "Antifreeze protein") | Certain plasma proteins of coldwater fish   
Interact with specific carbohydrates  | [Lectins](/wiki/Lectin "Lectin"), [selectins](/wiki/Selectin "Selectin") (cell adhesion lectins), antibodies   
[Receptor](/wiki/Receptor_\(biochemistry\) "Receptor \(biochemistry\)") | Various proteins involved in hormone and drug action   
Affect folding of certain proteins  | [Calnexin](/wiki/Calnexin "Calnexin"), [calreticulin](/wiki/Calreticulin "Calreticulin")  
Regulation of development  | [Notch](/wiki/Notch_signaling "Notch signaling") and its analogs, key proteins in development   
[Hemostasis](/wiki/Hemostasis "Hemostasis") (and [thrombosis](/wiki/Thrombosis "Thrombosis"))  | Specific glycoproteins on the surface membranes of [platelets](/wiki/Platelet "Platelet")  
  
## Analysis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Glycoprotein&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Analysis")]

A variety of methods used in detection, purification, and structural analysis
of glycoproteins are[4]:525[11][12]

Some important methods used to study glycoproteins  Method  | Use   
---|---  
[Periodic acid-Schiff stain](/wiki/Periodic_acid-Schiff_stain "Periodic acid-Schiff stain") | Detects glycoproteins as pink bands after [electrophoretic](/wiki/Electrophoresis "Electrophoresis") separation.   
Incubation of cultured cells with glycoproteins as [radioactive decay](/wiki/Radioactive_decay "Radioactive decay") bands  | Leads to detection of a radioactive sugar after electrophoretic separation.   
Treatment with appropriate [endo-](/wiki/Endoglycosidase "Endoglycosidase") or [exoglycosidase](/wiki/Exoglycosidase "Exoglycosidase") or [phospholipases](/wiki/Phospholipase "Phospholipase") | Resultant shifts in electrophoretic migration help distinguish among proteins with N-glycan, O-glycan, or GPI linkages and also between high [mannose](/wiki/Mannose "Mannose") and complex N-glycans.   
[Agarose](/wiki/Agarose "Agarose")-[lectin](/wiki/Lectin "Lectin") [column chromatography](/wiki/Column_chromatography "Column chromatography"), [lectin affinity chromatography](/wiki/Lectin_affinity_chromatography "Lectin affinity chromatography") | To purify glycoproteins or glycopeptides that bind the particular lectin used.   
[Lectin](/wiki/Lectin "Lectin") [affinity electrophoresis](/wiki/Affinity_electrophoresis "Affinity electrophoresis") | Resultant shifts in electrophoretic migration help distinguish and characterize [glycoforms](/wiki/Glycoform "Glycoform"), i.e. variants of a glycoprotein differing in carbohydrate.   
Compositional analysis following acid [hydrolysis](/wiki/Hydrolysis "Hydrolysis") | Identifies sugars that the glycoprotein contains and their stoichiometry.   
[Mass spectrometry](/wiki/Mass_spectrometry "Mass spectrometry") | Provides information on [molecular mass](/wiki/Molecular_mass "Molecular mass"), composition, sequence, and sometimes branching of a glycan chain. It can also be used for site-specific glycosylation profiling.[11]  
[NMR spectroscopy](/wiki/NMR_spectroscopy "NMR spectroscopy") | To identify specific sugars, their sequence, linkages, and the anomeric nature of glycosidic chain.   
[Multi-angle light scattering](/wiki/Multi-angle_light_scattering "Multi-angle light scattering") | In conjunction with size-exclusion chromatography, UV/Vis absorption and differential refractometry, provides information on [molecular mass](/wiki/Molecular_mass "Molecular mass"), protein-carbohydrate ratio, aggregation state, size, and sometimes branching of a glycan chain. In conjunction with composition-gradient analysis, analyzes self- and hetero-association to determine binding affinity and stoichiometry with proteins or carbohydrates in solution without labeling.   
[Dual Polarisation Interferometry](/wiki/Dual_Polarisation_Interferometry "Dual Polarisation Interferometry") | Measures the mechanisms underlying the biomolecular interactions, including reaction rates, affinities and associated [conformational changes](/wiki/Conformational_change "Conformational change").   
[Methylation](/wiki/Methylation "Methylation") (linkage) analysis  | To determine linkage between sugars.   
[Amino acid](/wiki/Amino_acid "Amino acid") or [cDNA](/wiki/Complementary_DNA "Complementary DNA") sequencing  | Determination of amino acid sequence.
